title: If Kim Jong-Un Opened A KFC, Would You Eat There?
summary:
Key ideas
- Philip Morris and KFC are pivoting to smoke-free and meatless options respectively
- Companies that formerly provided the "smoky meaty past" are now providing smoke-free meatless options
- There is a debate on whether or not to allow these companies to profit from their past bad behavior

Key learnings
- Tobacco-free cigarettes and meat substitutes have helped people quit smoking and become vegetarian, respectively
- It may be beneficial to let evil companies avoid punishment if they are willing to change their behavior
- Boycotting specific companies is difficult due to the existence of parent companies or subsidiary companies in their supply chain

Key questions
- Does allowing formerly evil companies to profit from positive change make a mockery of that change?
- Should companies be punished in order to encourage them to do good, or is the threat of punishment enough?
- What is the right course of action: punish evil companies regardless, let them avoid punishment if they change, or punish them after they have stopped doing evil?
